You know what, I think you're overthinking this again. Look, I've been at this company for 5 years - 2 years in office, 3 years remote. I can tell you exactly what the difference is.

In the office, we did have more random conversations and brainstorming sessions. People would bounce ideas off each other more casually. But we also had way more interruptions, pointless meetings, and people felt pressure to look busy even when they weren't being productive.

Remote, we're more focused and efficient. Our campaign quality hasn't dropped - if anything, people have more time to think deeply about concepts. But yeah, we've lost some of that spontaneous collaboration energy.

The thing is, my CEO romanticizes those hallway conversations, but half of them were just office gossip or complaining. The really good creative sessions were always planned anyway - the formal brainstorms, the strategy meetings, the client workshops.

So honestly? I think you were right the first time about hybrid. But not because of some research study - just because it makes practical sense. Get the best of both without the worst of either.

Does that sound right to you, or am I missing something?

<END>
